messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using PHP and the Laravel 11.x (laravel/framework ^11.28) framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. To begin this process, I'll provide you with the contents of file `app/Http/Controllers/Admin/PostThumbnailController.php`, your task is to extract all instances of API entries from this file.

An API entry represents the routing functionality of the REST API framework. It refers to the structure that binds a partial or complete request path (called a "path") to a function, class, class method, or object (called a "handler") that processes requests matching that path, either by handling them directly or by dispatching them to other handlers based on the path.

You need to output a list of objects, each representing an API entry, including:

- The HTTP request path, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}). Set this to null if it cannot be determined.
- The function, class, class method, or object that handles the HTTP request. Use exactly "anonymous" to denote an anonymous implementation.
- Whether the handler's implementation (i.e., processing requests and building responses) is present in the same source code file, rather than being imported.
- Whether the path string is a prefix rather than a full path.
- Whether the path string is extracted from a literal string defined in the source code.
- Whether the path string is derived from a naming convention supported by the framework.
- Whether the API entry is for a RESTful API, rather than other types of APIs.
- Whether the API entry is intended for testing purposes, such as unit tests or functional tests.

Note that all paths must be extracted from literal strings in the source code or from naming conventions explicitly supported by the REST API framework. Do not make guesses, if you find a function, class, class method, or object that looks a lot like an API implementation, but the path is not explicitly defined in this file (perhaps in another file), do not include it in your output. You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
[
  {
    "path": null,
    "handler": "App\\Http\\Controllers\\Admin\\PostThumbnailController::destroy",
    "implementation_in_same_file": true,
    "is_path_prefix": false,
    "is_path_literal": false,
    "is_path_derived_from_convention": false,
    "is_rest": true,
    "is_test": false
  }
]

Explanation:

- The file defines a single controller class App\Http\Controllers\Admin\PostThumbnailController with one public action destroy(Post $post). That method is present entirely in this file, so implementation_in_same_file is true and the handler is the class method shown above.
- There is no route path literal (no Route::... or attribute-based route string) in this file that maps an HTTP path to this method, so path is set to null and is_path_literal is false.
- Because the file does not declare any route prefix or route-group string, is_path_prefix is false.
- Although the method name destroy is conventionally used for a RESTful DELETE action in Laravel resource controllers, there is no explicit routing or resource registration shown here to derive the exact path from a naming convention in this file; therefore is_path_derived_from_convention is false. I still mark is_rest true because the method implements a typical RESTful "delete/unset" action (it unsets the post's thumbnail), but no HTTP verb or path is present in this file.
- The entry is not a test endpoint (is_test is false).
- No other API entries can be extracted from this file because no literal route paths or routing declarations are present here.
